title: Will Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff resign or be impeached before 1 April 2016?
preds: She bought herself enough time to make it past April 1. May 1, another story...
Senate vote date to be set by their Supreme Court - not going to happen today...

The impeachment has a few months to horse trade and politically decide if impeachment is a good decision for parties wanting to elect someone from their parties and who is going to have immunity, not in a few days.

A new opinion poll released Wednesday suggested just 10 percent of Brazilians have a favorable opinion of Rousseff. That's just slightly up from the single-digit approval ratings Rousseff faced last year, but still extremely low. The survey, by the Ibope polling agency, has a margin of error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. It was conducted from March 17-20, with 2,002 people interviewed nationwide.

For one thing, this is not going to happen in the next 2 days.  For another, the legislature is likely to delay voting on this until April or May.  As the economy deteriorates further, her enemies are playing for time to make it even more likely that she will be impeached.  She is not going to step down on her own, and has publicly said so multiple times.  Impeachments do not move fast enough for them to happen within the relevant time frame.
Yesterday Aljezzera News reported that Rousseff's political party is abandoning support for her, and there will be a vote to impeach her in about 2 weeks that has a good chance of succeeding!

The biggest party in the Brazilian congress, PMDB, just voted to abandon her ruling coalition. The party also voted to have its ministers in Rousseff's cabinet resign or face ethics proceedings.  Reports say this is most likely to create a domino effect which would make smaller parties follow increasing the chances of Rousseff losing the impeachment votes.  But the impeachment proceedings are most likely to start next month -the date of April 17 has been floating around - thus I will leave the forecast unchanged.

Brazil’s political upheaval enters a critical phase today, when the centrist Party of the Brazilian Democratic Movement will formally break with the president, depriving her of 69 votes out of 513 in Congress’s lower house. Ms Rousseff needs 172 to fend off impeachment—ostensibly over dodgy government accounting, but really over sleaze and economic incompetence. She has 110-odd in the bag. The PMDB’s departure vacates seven ministries, which her emissaries are offering to smaller parties in exchange for loyalty. Michel Temer, the PMDB boss, who as vice-president takes over if deputies vote to send impeachment proceedings to the Senate for trial, has also been busy over Easter, promising posts in his own putative administration. Tomorrow the Supreme Court weighs in: a procedural decision may hint whether it thinks Ms Rousseff tried to obstruct a corruption probe into prominent figures from her Workers’ Party. An unfavourable ruling would weaken her further—possibly fatally
-----NOTE----

Considering the April 1 deadline is coming up in around a week, it is unlikely Rousseff will resign or be impeached before that time. In order for impeachment to occur ⅔ of congress must be in support of impeachment and they are not scheduled to vote until April.

I believe that Dilma is nowhere near resigning, and is going to fight it to the end. Also, because the impeachment is going to proceed in April, she will not be impeached so unless a wild card lawyer happens, she will not be impeached. Therefore I give that a 0.5% chance which adds to a total of a 3% chance.

However, for her to be impeached, she needs to have ⅔ of their Chamber of Deputies turning against her, which won't happen before April 1 as these Deputies won't meet on these trials until April, making her impeachment before this deadline nigh impossible.

On Friday the clock started ticking for Dilma Rousseff. Congress’s lower house voted to start impeachment proceedings against the president, who has until early April to present her defence against charges of accounting trickery. Days earlier millions marched demanding her fall. Last week the Bar Association became the latest body to back the protesters. Ms Rousseff will be hoping that her 300,000-odd supporters who turned out on March 18th will sway at least 172 out of 513 deputies—the number she needs to avert trial by the Senate. Last week she appointed as chief of staff Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, her wily predecessor, to help cajole congressmen. But the move was blocked by a Supreme Court judge, who argued that its purpose was to shield Lula from a corruption probe. The government is appealing to the full tribunal, which won’t meet for another week. A tense Easter beckons

Dateline 3-18-16 “Impeachment is all about politics, and although the Lava Jato investigation seems to be marching inexorably toward the upper rungs of the political establishment, there is as yet no smoking gun against Rousseff that would tip the scales. There is evidence of massive campaign violations, confirmation of the kickbacks that helped convict Odebrecht, and allegations of government meddling in the courts. Yesterday’s wiretapped conversation with Lula also puts Rousseff in an unpalatable position, but the presidential palace has claimed that there was good justification for the conversation. Because of the legitimacy concerns noted above, none of these, as yet, seems sufficient to generate the momentum needed in the final push for impeachment, especially in the context of a rudderless, divided, and increasingly discredited opposition,” writes CFR's Matthew Taylor. Even though it seems likely that Dilma will be forced out of office, this will not happen before April 1st. In Brazil’s history, the previous impeachment attempt in 1992 (of Collor) took several months to be brought to the Senate (from the Chamber of Deputies). Even after impeachment has been brought to the Senate, Collor did not resign until two-three months after the start of the Senate proceedings. Since the lower house has not yet impeached Dilma, it is extremely unlikely that Dilma will resign or be impeached before the deadline.

In reviewing some history that leads up to where we are now with this question, it seems that, at least in terms of the broadest allegations, there is nothing new that was not already foreshadowed years ago when the Petrobas scandal first broke. Even then, from its very inception, there were signs that it would lead directly to Lula and Dilma. Here we are now, three years later, and they're still around. This makes a strong argument for them, or at least Dilma, "being around" for a lot longer, well beyond the horizon of this question. In thinking about an inspiring article provided by @000, however, I am also thinking that we shall begin to see a new set of social phenomena that may not yet have been recognized or articulated. It may not occur in Brazil, or maybe it will. It can be generally described as an awakening to the notion that: "Error had been routed, and now science could advance." I'm thinking it's a notion, still formative, seeking representation (expression) through communicative symbols. Maybe it will blossom in Brazil this week. It's a notion that, once embodied, will cause even the most ardent communist worker to pause, reflect, and say: "They have dragged this country through three years of total crap and they were aware of the "error" the entire time." Again, think about this. An "error" was alleged three years ago. An epistemological error. Those in the position to correct this error remained silent, causing millions to remain in error, for three years. Maybe I am wrong, and this is not a new element in the current psyche, or not a matured element, or neither in Brazil. It probably won't happen this week. It hasn't happened for three years. I'm thinking it is a possibility though; a form of overcoming politics with science.

Impeachment proceedings for Dilma Rousseff began in December of 2015. There has been some substantial progress with the proceedings since then, and Barclays’ Bruno Rovai wrote to clients that Rousseff’s chances of impeachment were rising once again. Over the last week her campaign manager was arrested over illegal payments received in his party’s offshore accounts. Also Rousseff’s own party is disagreeing with her economic agenda, and social movements have started showing signs of not approving of her agenda (there are protests scheduled for March 13). Rousseff’s approval rating is 11, down from 12% in December. Rovai personally believes that “the longer the impeachment process lies in the House of Representatives, the higher the likelihood that it will be approved.” Therefore it seems like Rousseff will be impeached eventually, just not necessarily within the month. The House of Representatives has been very slow-moving up to this point, therefore I do not think that there will be a mad rush to impeach her as soon as possible.

What's becoming ever more clear in this Petrobas / Rousseff scandal is that the corruption: a) has been going for a very long-time across multiple administrations, and b) that it was seemingly "brought into" Brazil in some fashion. That is, it is not the result of a scheme that spontaneously created itself out of some random collection of transactions and indigenous individuals. It is far too comprehensive and inter-connected for that. It has individuals participating in activities that are out of the realm of their personal expertise. Many, many people performing functions, yet none seemingly sophisticated or capable enough to organize those functions. So I'm beginning to think the Brazilian thing tied into a pre-existing international network rather than just mushrooming from any set of internal schemes. These participants have been taught how to engage in such interrelated complexity on a massive scale. I haven't followed the scandal in detail at all really, so I do not know, but it's beginning to smell that way. I'll be curious to learn if this recent Santana catch is just another role participant, or more of an overall organizer.

This is not a prediction update, since I kept my previous estimate of 3%: I just want to remark that there is an alternative scenario gaining momentum, that could lead to President Rouseeff leaving office: campaign contestation ('impugnação' in Portuguese). This is not the same as resignation neither impeachment. Resignation would require President Rousseff choosing to leave office; Impeachment would require both Parlament Houses to agree that President Rousseff should indeed leave office; 'Impugnação de Campanha' or campaign contestation would require the Highest Electoral Court (TSE - Tribunal Superior Eleitoral) to agree that her campaign was improperly conducted. With the provisional arrest of João Santana, who was President Rousseff's campaign manager in 2010 and 2014 and also Lula's in 2006, it seems that part of the money illegally extracted from Petrobras was employed in President Rousseff's last campaign, and possibly in campaigns of some of her allies.
At this point in time, given the overall fragility of Parlament Houses and popular unrest, it seems to me that 'impugnação' became more feasible. And, if Parlament Reps are seeing things the way I described, I bet they would be less motivated to risk their public positions to pursue Rousseff's impeachment. I will wait to see if there are any signs of this 'sudden unwillingness' emerging among Parlament Reps before I get it reflected in my forecast.

An impeachment or resignation by Rouseff is within the realm of possibility before the end of her term, but highly unlikely before April 1st (7 weeks from now). The Brazilian Constitution specifies that a maximum of 180 days can be allowed to conclude a trial. Impeachment requires a 2/3 vote in the Chamber of Deputies, but of the 513 seats, the opposition has 199. Therefore, 145 members of her own coalition would have to vote to impeach. Given the current climate (the zika virus, a worsening economy, the corruption scandal with Petrobras), an impeachment can certainly occur, just not in the next 7 weeks.

I am from Brazil, and have been accompanying this process very closely. It is virtually impossible that it will happen in this time frame. The regular impeachment process would require approval by 2/3 of the chamber of deputies and 2/3 of the congress after a very long investigation conducted by a group of people elected by the political parties in these government houses. The Federal Supreme Court has established rules that difficult the process even more, decreasing the likelihood of its success. Finally, there still needs to appear a scandal involving the president that will be strong enough to draw popular attention and force her to resign.

I think it is unlikely that an impeachment will occur by 1 April.  It would be a very rushed action.  Parliamentary action (especially in coalition governments) tends to proceed slowly.  However, I am not an expert on Brazilian politics.

Given the recent ruling made by the Brazilian Supreme Court, it appears highly unlikely Ms. Rousseff will be impeached - or resign - before 1 April 2016.  It appears the Brazilian Senate now has a large say in the matter, and the current government has a more stable majority in that chamber.

Impeachment Steps are: 1) impeachment request, 2) form impeachment committee, 3) President has 10 sessions to present case, 4) committee has 5 sessions to prepare report, 5) committee reports decision to full chamber, 6) 2/3 vote in lower house required, 7) Senate convenes a trial, 8) Impeachment if 2/3 vote of Senate; Step 1 is complete, but step 2 must be redone per the Supreme Court. Not back in session until February 1. Also, In another positive sign for Rousseff, the Supreme Court also ruled that the Senate can review the grounds for impeachment, even if the lower house votes to impeach her, through a simple majority.

Very unpopular and does not have the support of legislators, but no vote can take place before Feb. impeachment in 1992 was started in Sep 92 and Collor resigned  in December 92. So unlikely that process could be completed by 1 Apr, but she could resign by then.

Then, if it wins, Rousseff will be impeached. And all of it must happens during carnaval and with the Olimpic Games coming in close. Seems too much to be done before April.

There have been many good comments on this issue since it opened, so I won't repeat them here. For me, the key points against impeachment are 
1. Brazil's economy is in a mess and a sane politician would rather not take over at this time.
2. With the high profile Olympics this year, political upheavals would be bad for Brazil's international image.
3. The Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, now one of Roussef's key opponents, is facing grave legal problems himself, which reduces his credibility.
4. It is very unlikely that one third of the Chamber won't support her against a motion calling for legal proceedings, given the number of seats her party currently holds. So far nothing has been made public that would weaken her standing within the party.
5. It looks like no further proceedings will happen on this matter until March, which gets too close to the deadline.
6. She won't go quietly and is likely to fight all the way to the end if necessary.

Senator Acir Gurgacz, who is charged with reporting to the committee on a ruling by Brazil’s Federal Audit Court that the Rousseff administration broke the law by disguising spending last year, said he recommends approving the 2014 accounts.
Rousseff’s opponents are seeking to impeach her alleging that she broke Brazil’s budget law by resorting to accounting tricks to hide greater public spending aimed at boosting the economy during her re-election campaign last year.

Given that the Brazilian Congress has decided to take a recess until 1 February 2016, despite the urgency inherent to any impeachment process, it is highly unlikely that there will be a final decision on the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff before 1 April 2016. Add to the fact that a recent decision by the Brazilian Supreme Court has stalled the process even further since the political moves of Ms Rousseff's greatest foe and President of the Brazilian Lower House of Congress, Eduardo Cunha, were found illegal, thus calling for another vote on the committee responsible for analyzing the impeachment request. As to the possibility of Ms Rousseff resigning from office, past experience has shown that it is not in her nature to give in to political pressure, let alone own up to any wrongdoings or shortcomings relating to herself or any of her underlings, thereby warranting the conclusion of a slim chance of resignation. On the other hand, the nomination of Mr Nelson Barbosa as Finance Minister signals more of the same, i.e., that Ms Rousseff is back at the helm of economic decisions, which has already met with a backlash from the financial markets, and may add to the outcry of the Brazilian population, whose disapproval of the current administration is at 67% of the general population according to Datafolha. This could mean that more people are likely to throng to the streets in the coming months so as to make Ms Rousseff reconsider her position as head of State, which justifies a slight 5% chance of resignation before 1 April 2016.

There are now two points that lead to the answer of this question. The first is: "Is there enough time before 1 April 2016?"
As I see it, the answer is "Barely." The congressmen in Brazil go into recess by the end of December and return only by the beginning of February. There are a lot of steps to go, involving two reports by the special comission of the Chamber of Deputies, two votes by the Chamber as a whole, ratifying the accusation and a judgement by the Senate, each with it's own term. The opposition is moving, trying to get the Chamber to vote in January, but it is unlikely that they will succeed.
The second question is the outcome of the votes. And that depends strongly on the popular support to the impeachment process, which by now is unpredictable. There are distinct sectors of the population supporting each side, and the final outcome may depend on a crucial fact, such as a piece of evidence appearing against Rousseff, or a public outcry after a confrontation results in a death on one of the sides.
I'd say that the chance that she will be eventually impeached is around 30% - 40%, while the chance that she is by April 1st is much lower.

Reducing my forecast. Couple of factors at play: 

(1) Congress and the Judiciary are about to enter a December recess and doesn't sound like they will be back until February. This leaves limited time for impeachment proceedings to start and conclude before April.

While corruption has engulfed the ruling party and the opposition, movement toward resignation or impeached is currently constrained by this factor primarily.  The distribution of influence, power among competing interests and perceptions of the electorate seems to have created a situation of governance stasis or equilibrium that cements a status quo dynamic that increases political and economic instability.
Opposition appears to be in disarray over this issue.
Highly unlikely - he is on his way out anyway, and with the Olympics looming the negative image this would project of Brazil on the world stage would not be favourable to any replacement.

Backroom  deals that make it unlikely that the president of the lower house will be removed, and other deals with powerful senators connected to the "national campions" industries have reduced considerably the possibility that Rousseff will be impeached during the time frame. President Dilma Rousseff has suffered several losses in a short period of time...
(a) she has been defeated in Congress in many of her proposals to reform the economy.
(b) she is the target of an investigation by the TSE (top electoral authority). The TSE is looking into irregularities in President Dilma Rousseff's re-election campaign last year. The TSE is seeking to determine whether Rousseff abused her power while in office to run the campaign, and whether illegal money was used as funding.
(c)  the 2014 spending accounts for Rousseff's government was not approved by the TCU due to several irregularities in the accounts – and the last time that happen was in 1937! Note: the TCU is equivalent to the U.S. Government Accountability Office – GAO. 
(d) Rousseff shrank her cabinet and reshuffled ministers on last week (October 2nd) to bolster alliances within her coalition government and block efforts to impeach her. However, that alliance has proven to be ineffective so far and did not strengthen her coalition's ties to lawmakers needed to help re-balance public finances.

http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-16/brazil-s-opposition-takes-most-decisive-steps-toward-impeachment
Brazil’s opposition leaders this week are taking the most decisive steps so far to try and remove President Dilma Rousseff from office amid growing discontent over her handling of a tanking economy.
Lawmakers this week for the first time formally discussed the procedures for impeachment on the floor of the lower house, asking the head of the chamber, Eduardo Cunha, for clarification on the steps required to start a process to oust the president. Brazil’s largest opposition parties now are rallying behind an impeachment request filed by Helio Bicudo, a co-founder and former member of Rousseff’s ruling Workers’ Party.
...
Many legislators remain loyal to Rousseff and party leaders from the governing coalition this week denounced attempts to remove her from office, saying such a move would be a break with constitutional rule.
...
“A vote on impeachment as early as this year is possible, but I can’t say that categorically,” Jose Mendonca Filho, leader of Brazil’s second biggest opposition party, said Wednesday. “From the political point of view, the questions presented on the floor yesterday were the first step toward the debate over the vote on President Dilma’s impeachment.”
...
Bicudo says Rousseff should be held responsible and impeached for doctoring her government’s financial accounts, breaking campaign finance laws and allowing state-run oil company Petrobras to incur losses because of corruption.
...
If impeachment proceedings are accepted by Cunha or the majority of lawmakers, a committee will discuss the request and send its recommendation to the house floor. At least 342 out of 513 lawmakers must vote for impeachment hearings to begin before the case goes to the Senate or Supreme Court, depending on the charges.
Cunha already rejected five of the 18 impeachment requests sent to Congress, saying they don’t pass legal muster.

"Most members of Brazil’s audit court known as the TCU are leaning toward a ruling against Rousseff, the people said, asking not to be named when speaking about future votes. Pressure from civil society makes it difficult for court members to go back on a preliminary June decision that said Rousseff’s 2014 accounting practices were illegal, they said.

Also on Tuesday, opposition parties formally questioned the lower house president on procedural issues involving impeachment."

Impeachment or resignation for other reasons by 1 April 2016 is highly unlikely, particularly because it would further damage the reputation of Latin America's largest "democracy" and further complicate financial markets that are active in the world's 7th largest economy.  The New York Times, The Financial Times of London and El Pais in Madrid have run editorials and op-ed pieces propagating this view. The Financial Times doubled down on this point by editorializing that possible early elections, and the scheduled 2018 presidential election will produce a field mediocre candidates who are ethically challenged anyhow.  The survivability of Dilma's unraveling Workers' Party coalition is a story that has legs and has taken on the drama of a daily political telenovela.   The situation could change if a second major credit rating agency follows Standard & Poors and downgrades Brazil's sovereign debt to junk. Remember, in France, president Hollande has been governing with a 10 percent approval rating but his use of the French armed forces in support of US and NATO operatings against Daesh-ISIS has strong support among the body politic. Dilma does not have any wiggle room or political equity and while she will project the essence of presidential power the realpolitk is being brokered in the backrooms of Brazilian politics by other power players like the president of Congress, Senator Renan Calheiros, a 4 time president of the senate. The internecine warfare continues.

Rousseff may be unpopular at the moment, but it does not seem likely that she will resign or be impeached in the immediate future. As Jean-Pierre points out below, the bar needed to pursue an impeachment is quite high and a large part of the governing coalition would need to turn on Rousseff to make it happen. Resignation seems like the more probable of the two options. Even then, pressure to resign seems to mostly be coming from opposition parties, rather than from within the governing coalition at the moment.

The forecasting window is too short and there is no easy mechanism to remove a president. The quickest way to do it would be a military coup, but the question omits that possibility. Impeachment proceedings take time. The Brazilian Constitution allows for a maximum of 180 days to conclude a trial. The vote threshold is very high. Impeachment in Brazil requires a 2/3 vote in the Chamber of Deputies (513 seats). The governing coalition has 285 members while the opposition has 199. So, the opposition would need to pick up 145 defectors to get to the magic number 344. This won't happen, in my opinion, unless the corruption scandals touch her personally. Low approval ratings alone won't do it.
